Let's assume that the prior probability of the product being high-quality is 0.8. The likelihood of 0 high-quality products being sold out of 3 purchases given that the product is low-quality is 1, and the likelihood of 0 high-quality products being sold out of 3 purchases given that the product is high-quality is (0.2)^3 = 0.008. The posterior probability of the product being high-quality is then (0.8 * 0.008) / ((0.8 * 0.008) + (0.2 * 1)) = 0.016. This is lower than my prior probability, so I will pass on the product.
